Award.AwardTitle: CDI-Type II: Collaborative Research: Dynamical processes in interdependent techno-social networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The significant advances realized in recent years in the study of complex networks are severely limited by an almost exclusive focus on the behavior of single networks. However, most networks in the real world are not isolated but are coupled and hence depend upon other networks, which in turn depend upon other networks. Real networks communicate with each other and may exchange information, or, more importantly, may rely upon one another for their proper functioning. A simple but real example is a power station network that depends on a computer network, and the computer network depends on the power network. Our social networks depend on technical networks, which, in turn, are supported by organizational networks. Surprisingly, analyzing complex systems as coupled interdependent networks alters the most basic assumptions that network theory has relied on for single networks. A multidisciplinary, data driven research project will: 1) Study the microscopic processes that rule the dynamics of interdependent networks, with a particular focus on the social component; 2) Define new mathematical models/foundational theories for the analysis of the robustness/resilience and contagion/diffusive dynamics of interdependent networks. This project will afford the opportunity of greatly expanding the understanding of realistic complex networks by joining theoretical analysis of coupled networks with extensive analysis of appropriately chosen large-scale databases. These databases will be made publicly available, except for special cases where it is illegal to do so.

This research has important implications for the understanding the social and technical systems that make up a modern society. A recent US Scientific Congressional Report concludes ?No currently available modeling and simulation tools exist that can adequately address the consequences of disruptions and failures occurring simultaneously in different critical infrastructures that are dynamically inter-dependent.? Understanding the interdependence of networks and its effect on the system robustness and on the structural and functional behavior is crucial for properly modeling many real world systems and applications, from disaster preparedness, to building effective organizations, to comprehending the complexity of the macro economy. In addition to these intellectual objectives, the research project includes the development of an extensive outreach program to the public, especially K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Life as we know it in the modern world is increasingly dependent on an intricate web of critical infrastructure systems. The failure or damage of electric power, telecommunications, transportation and water supply systems would cause huge social disruptions. While potential dangers lurk within each particular infrastructure, recent disasters have shown that the most dangerous vulnerability is hiding in the many interdependencies across different infrastructures. Relatively localized damage in one system may lead to failure in another, triggering a disruptive avalanche of cascading and escalating failures. Understanding the fragility induced by multiple interdependencies is one of the major challenges in the design of resilient infrastructures.
Although the work on the resilience of complex networks has triggered enormous interest and debate, most studies have been focused on single isolated networks. Such a situation is, however, more an exception than the norm. Infrastructures show a large number of interdependencies of a different nature:  physical interdependency when energy, material or people flow from one infrastructure to another; cyber interdependency when information is transmitted or exchanged; geographic interdependency signaling the co-location of infrastructures’ elements; logical interdependency that signal financial, political coordination, etc. interactions.
     We could attack this formidable problem because of the network science and computational social science  revolutions, based on massive archives of digital trace data on human behavior, combined with the power of 21st century computers. We carried out a multidisciplinary research project to study for the first time:
     — Microscopic processes ruling the dynamics of interdependent networks, especially when the social component is included in the system.
     — New mathematical models/foundational theories for the analysis of the robustness and resilience of interdependent networks.
     — Models for contagion spreading and diffusive process in interdependent and heterogeneous networks.
     Our research led to a paradigm shift in the development of a theoretical framework for the simultaneous modeling of heterogeneous, interdependent networks. The major problem is not each infrastructure “per se” but the combination of infrastructures and the behavior of people using those infrastructures. Our main result can be summarized as a breakthrough in the application of complex systems and network theory to the modeling and analysis of the integration of social interactions and technological and communication networks. Our main results are:
(i) Introduced and developed the framework for characterizing, modeling, analyzing and understanding coupled networks. We used analytical approaches and numerical techniques, as well as new concepts and measures based on statistical physics approaches, such as percolation, generating functions, and scaling theory, to study general classes of interconnected networks. Our framework incorporates: (a) different topologies for the coupled network components, (b) various types of inter-connections among these components and (c) definitions of new measures and properties to characterise coupled network systems. We focused on robustness and found significant important structural and functional features of coupled network behaviour.
(ii) Studied the structural and functional properties of different types of coupled networks by introducing new approaches and tools. We found that inter-connections under different conditions can be either harmful (e.g., cascading failures) or beneficial to coupled network operation (e.g., enhanced transport). We (a) discovered such features of dynamical processes as epidemic and transport in coupled networks, (b) now understand such topological features as optimal and shortest path and (c) have determined how the coupled network structure affects its function.
(iii) Developed new concepts and strategies towards controlling and optimizing robustness and functionality of coupled networks. We developed strategies for improving robustness and transport properties that allow better control of epidemics through efficient immunization. We achieved this by: (a) developing approaches for maximizing/minimizing the size of the largest connected cluster under different types of attacks/immunization strategies and (b) developing algorithms and protocols for transport that reduce congestion and avoid bottlenecks.
     This project addressed the unconventional complexity of the problem, namely the richness of coupled networks. It considered many classes of coupled networks with components of different topologies and various types of interactions between the components. We found that the coupling between different topologies leads to new rich and complex phenomena.
     The development of a mathematical framework provided new analytical and empirical tools for the analysis of coupled network systems, and led to novel insights and applications. We collected many coupled network datasets and studied them using a coupled network approach. As an outcome of the project we now have systematic tools that both improve robustness and prevent cascading failures in infrastructure coupled networks, and we have strategies for the efficient immunisation of interconnected networks.
